abstract.p: This paper presents a modularized, easy-to-implement framework for predictive maintenance scheduling. With a modularization treatment of a maintenance scheduling model, a predictive maintenance scheduling model can be established by integrating components’ real-time, sensory-updated prognostics information with a classical preventive maintenance/condition-based maintenance scheduling model. With the framework, a predictive maintenance scheduling model for multi-component systems is established to illustrate the framework’s use; such a predictive maintenance scheduling model for multi-component systems has not been reported previously in the literature. A numerical example is provided to investigate the individual-orientation and dynamic updating characteristics of the optimal preventive maintenance schedules of the established predictive maintenance scheduling model and to evaluate the performance of these preventive maintenance schedules. It is hoped that the presented framework will facilitate the implementation of predictive maintenance policies in various industrial applications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The importance and complexity of maintenance have been widely recognized in today’s competitive market. In recent decades, we have witnessed the shift of maintenance strategies from corrective maintenance (CM), time-based preventive maintenance (PM), to condition-based maintenance (CBM) and predictive maintenance (PdM).1 As many systems undergo degradation processes which can be reflected by a change of states (e.g. crack length) or performance (e.g. vibration amplitude),2 CBM and PdM have shown to be more effective in machine downtime reduction, maintenance cost reduction, inventory reduction, logistics and supply chain enhancement, and operation safety enhancement.1,3

As an essential element of a maintenance program, maintenance scheduling has consistently been an interesting topic for researchers since the 1960s.4 In the literature, there is a huge number of maintenance scheduling models, most of which are PM scheduling models and CBM scheduling models.1,5,6 PM scheduling models are typically established based on system lifetime distributions fitted from the historical failure and censoring data of a batch of identical systems.5,6 CBM scheduling models are typically established based on stochastic degradation models,7,8 Markov/hidden Markov degradation models,9,10 and so on Both PM and CBM scheduling models are built upon the population characteristics, and therefore are applicable to a system population. In addition, the optimal maintenance schedules in a PM/CBM scheduling model are fixed once determined, regardless of the real-time degradation signals of a specific system.

Differently, a PdM scheduling model is built upon the predicted degradation signals of a specific system, given its degradation signals up to the current moment. Consequently, the calculated optimal PM schedules are applicable only to the specific system being monitored. Moreover, the optimal PM schedules from a PdM scheduling model are dynamically updated in real time, when more system degradation signals are collected and made available.11–14

In the literature, there are very limited PdM scheduling models reported.11–19 Christer et al.11 developed a replacement action decision aid for a key furnace component using a state space condition monitoring model. Pedregal and Carnero12 developed a system for condition monitoring in order to carry out the maintenance of a critical turbine driving a centrifugal compressor, using a similar state space model to that presented by Christer et al.11 Lu et al.13 developed a PdM model to minimize the overall maintenance costs, different from the objective of minimizing maintenance cost per unit time in Christer et al.11 and Pedregal and Carnero.12 Wu et al.14 developed an integrated neural-network-based decision support system for PdM of rotational equipment to minimize the maintenance cost per unit operational time. Kaiser and Gebraeel15 presented a PdM policy based on a sensory-updated degradation model to minimize the overall maintenance costs. Kaiser and Gebraeel’s comparative study15 provides evidence that PdM scheduling models are more effective than the corresponding PM and CBM scheduling models in reducing overall maintenance costs, based on a simulation model of a manufacturing cell. A control-limit PdM policy was proposed by Li et al.16 to minimize the expected maintenance costs per unit operational time of components subject to imperfect PM acts. Li et al.’s work16 was extended to a sequential PdM policy by the present authors.17 We developed a PdM framework that integrates PM policies and residual life prediction models aiming at maximizing long-term average availability.18 Recently, Ahmadi and Newby19 outlined a new approach to the maintenance scheduling of a manufacturing system using an intensity control model. By the use of Ahmadi and Newby’s model,19 the optimal inspection strategy and optimal repair policy are jointly determined to optimize manufacturing revenue.

Most, if not all, reported PdM scheduling models are originally developed for single-component systems.11–19 Consequently, advances in PdM scheduling could be the development of more single-component system PdM scheduling models considering other practical objectives, maintenance policies, maintenance quality, and maintenance constraints. However, it is more important to work on PdM scheduling models for multi-component systems.

Instead of developing the above-mentioned PdM scheduling models one by one, this paper presents a generic, easy-to-implement framework for PdM scheduling. By splitting a PdM scheduling model into several modules, it shows that a PdM scheduling model can be established by integrating components’ real-time prognostics information with classical PM/CBM models, without significant modifications. This means that one can refer to many existing PM and CBM scheduling models when developing a PdM scheduling model. With the presented framework, a PdM scheduling model is established for multi-component serial systems, which has not been reported previously in the literature. A numerical experiment is conducted to investigate the characteristics of the optimal PM schedules of the PdM scheduling model and to evaluate the performance of the PM schedules.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. The next section presents the modularized framework for PdM scheduling, details several key technical elements, and gives an example PdM scheduling model for multi-component serial systems. Then the numerical experiment is conducted for further analysis. Finally, some concluding remarks are given and future directions are discussed.

sec.title: The modularized PdM scheduling framework
sec.p: This section presents the modularized PdM scheduling framework. First the general structure of the framework is outlined. Next an example PdM scheduling model for multi-component serial systems is given for illustration, after which several technical details in the example PdM scheduling model are discussed.

sec.title: Framework structure
sec.p: The PdM scheduling framework is established by analyzing the essential elements of a maintenance scheduling model and separating them into several modules. By analyzing various PM/CBM/PdM scheduling models, it is necessary to define the following elements to fully establish a maintenance scheduling model;

list-item.p: Objective (Obj). The goal of a maintenance program, which could be minimization of overall losses in a finite time horizon,20 minimization of maintenance cost ratio in an infinite time horizon,21 maximization of average availability in an infinite time horizon,7 and so on.
Maintenance policy (MP). The relationship between the consecutive PM acts, which could be periodic policy,22 control limit policy,11 sequential policy,21 and so on.

Maintenance constraints (MC). The conditions that must be satisfied when performing maintenance acts, which could be a short-run system availability constraint,7 the availability of maintenance spare parts,20 and so on.

Degradation models (DM). The models that characterize the degradation process of a system or a population of systems before any maintenance act, which could be system lifetime distributions,5,6 stochastic processes,7,8 Markov/hidden Markov processes,9,10 the predicted time series of the degradation signals,11–18 and so on. The degradation models are further used to estimate system failure likelihood.

Maintenance effect (ME). The degree to which a system recovers after a CM act or a PM act, which could be perfect maintenance which restores a system to a state “as good as new”, imperfect maintenance which restores a system to a better state but not “as good as new”, minimal maintenance which makes a system operational but “as good as old”,5,6 and so on.

sec.p: In formulating a PdM policy, the above elements can be further divided into three modules:

list-item.p: objective module which contains element Obj and determines the general functional form of the objective function of a maintenance scheduling model;
policy module which contains elements MP and MC and determines the relationship between the schedules of maintenance acts (especially PM acts);
degradation & recovery module which contains elements DM and ME and calculates the system failure likelihood and expected number of failures between consecutive PM acts.

sec.p: Table 1 lists several maintenance scheduling models for illustration. In Table 1 the only difference between a PdM scheduling model and a PM/CBM scheduling model is the degradation & recovery module, which is used to calculate the system’s failure likelihood. While the degradation & recovery module of a PM/CBM scheduling model uses population-oriented degradation models to calculate static components’ failure likelihood, the degradation & recovery module of a PdM scheduling model uses individual-oriented degradation models to calculate and dynamically update the components’ failure likelihood at each sampling point. Therefore, by replacing the static failure likelihood information in many existing classical PM/CBM scheduling models with dynamically updated failure likelihood estimated from real-time sensor signals reflecting the components’ states, a PdM scheduling model is attainable. Due to the dynamic nature of the PM schedules from a PdM scheduling model, an updating stopping module is further needed to stop model updates in real time and decide the moment for performing PM acts.

sec.p: In Figure 9, most testing components share a same cumulative cost as they have the same PM schedules and do not fail before the PM schedules. Particularly, testing sample #43 fails at time t = 49 according to the PM schedules and consequently an expensive failure loss is incurred. From the results in Figure 9, the average cumulative cost for the 50 testing samples is $6590.

Comparing the average cost of $3988.6 in the PdM scheduling model with the counterpart $6590 in the PM scheduling model shows that, for the current case, the PdM scheduling model significantly outperforms the PM scheduling model in maintenance cost saving and failure prevention by considering each component’s real-time degradation signals.

It is worth mentioning that the optimal PM schedules in Figures 5 and 6 are very different, as testing sample #21 and testing sample #22 have different real-time degradation signals. However, the optimal PM schedules in the corresponding PM scheduling model are same for the entire population (Figure 8). Therefore, the individual-orientation characteristics of the optimal PM schedules in a PdM scheduling model are different from the population-orientation characteristics of the optimal PM schedules in a PM scheduling model. Moreover, the optimal PM schedules in a PdM scheduling model are dynamically updated with more degradation signals sampled, and this is again very different from the static characteristics of the optimal PM schedules in a PM scheduling model.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p: This paper presents a modularized framework for PdM scheduling. By splitting a PdM scheduling model into several modules, a PdM scheduling model can be established by integrating classical PM/CBM scheduling models and components’ failure likelihood predicted by its real-time degradation signals, without significant modifications. Currently there is already a huge number of PM/CBM scheduling models for predicting a component’s degradation-based failure likelihood. With the modularized framework, an example PdM scheduling model for multi-component serial systems is presented for detailed illustration. A numerical experiment based on a typical degradation model is conducted to analyze the characteristics of the optimal PM schedules for the PdM scheduling models and evaluate the performance of these PM schedules. The experimental results show the superiority of the PdM scheduling model over the corresponding PM scheduling model in terms of a significant reduction in average cumulative cost. More importantly, the experimental results highlight the individual-orientation and dynamic updating characteristics of the optimal PM schedules for a PdM scheduling model, which are different from the population-orientation and static characteristics of the optimal PM schedules for a PM scheduling model.

We believe the presented framework may facilitate the implementation of PdM scheduling models in industrial applications. In the future, it would be interesting to conduct a more in-depth study of the updating stopping module to further improve the performance of PdM scheduling models. In addition, a real case study on PdM scheduling is needed for further validation and insights.
